title: Adding and Subtracting Fractions
goal: Teach kids how to add and subtract fractions with the same and different denominators.
summary: Fractions are fair shares. To add or subtract them, make sure the pieces (denominators) match. If they already match, just work with the numerators. If they don't, change them into matching pieces first.

sections.heading: Step 1: When the bottoms match (same denominator)
sections.kid_friendly_explanation: If the bottoms are the same, the pieces are the same size. Add or subtract only the top numbers, and keep the bottom number.

example.story: You have 2 slices of the same pizza and your friend gives you 1 more slice. Each slice is a quarter pizza.
example.explanation: The slices are all fourths, so we add the tops: 2 + 1 = 3. Keep the bottom 4.

sections.heading: Step 2: When the bottoms don't match (different denominators)
sections.kid_friendly_explanation: Make the pieces the same size first. Find an equal way to slice both fractions so their bottoms match. A simple way is to use the Least Common Denominator (LCD).
how_to: Rewrite each fraction so it uses the LCD.
Now add or subtract the numerators and keep the common denominator.
key_formulas_latex: \frac{a}{b} + \frac{c}{d} = \frac{ad + bc}{bd} \quad (\text{if you use } bd \text{ as a common denominator})

example.story: Skittles time! You ate 1/3 of a bag and later 1/6 of a bag. How much in total?
example.explanation: Change thirds into sixths so the pieces match, then add. Finally, simplify.

sections.heading: Step 3: Simplify your answer
sections.kid_friendly_explanation: If your fraction can be shrunk, divide the top and bottom by the same number.
sections.key_formula_latex: \frac{a}{b} = \frac{a \div k}{b \div k} \;\text{when } k \text{ divides both } a \text{ and } b

example.story: 2/4 of a chocolate bar is the same as 1/2.

vocabulary.kid_friendly_definition: The top number that counts how many pieces you have.
The bottom number that tells how many equal pieces make a whole.
The smallest bottom number both fractions can share.
Make a fraction smaller but equal by dividing the top and bottom by the same number.
